reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a positive review because I do like this game a lot, but that said, it has some problems. It's sort of like a Dwarf Fortress Lite game, which makes me long for DF and realize how intelligently DF (despite its UI issues) is designed.

This review will be updated regularly.


Pros:
- Nice gameplay graphics.
- Most game elements are fairly intuitive. (Though some of the buildings could use a bit more in-game instruction, like the elevator, but that's obviously not a priority in Early Access.)
- The spells are a great way to engage the player, and are very useful, though mana recharge takes a while.
- Controls are generally intuitive and work well.
- Controlling an individual dwarf is generally very effective, though controlling the individual's movement relative the landscape can sometimes be tricky, and it's hard to execute some of the maneuvers dwarves do on their own.


Cons:

- Crappy UI graphics. The UI could be improved upon design-wise, and made to supply more information (like how long until nightfall, etc.)
- UPDATE 5/29: They've updated the UI. It looks much better now, and has more functionality. Will update further when I have a chance to really sit down and play for a few hours to explore the new UI. :)

- The drag and drop crafting system is extremely annoying. Make me do it once to start, sure, but offer an autofill option?

- Needs recycling or selling items, I have a bunch of goblin crap I don't need.

- Dwarves can't handle their own food supplies. When you get a lot of dwarves, they go through that food pretty fast, and you have to manually tell them to cook it, and also manually click a bunch to put it out on the table! Really makes me wish it had a system like DF where you just tell the dwarves what they can eat and cook with, and they'll automatically go get their own food. Maybe what CtW needs is a larder object where food is automatically stored, and dwarves can get it from the larder and bring it to tables themselves?

- Enemy raids happen too often. Late in the game, you often have to go very far afield to gather resources, and while elevators and rails are helpful, it's still a lot of travel time. So here I am, working at the edge of the map, and suddenly I have to abandon everything I'm doing and send everyone back to base because a raid is happening. Probably ten minutes out of every hour is spent dealing with stupid raids, and the defensive towers you can build aren't effective enough. Basically your tower has to be so close to the ground to hit an enemy that they can reach it and take it out easily. Towers also aren't very powerful, meaning nearly every assault (even some minor, regular nighttime ones) requires your attention to dispatch dwarves away from whatever more productive thing they could be doing. I am presently trying to figure out a way to just prevent raiders from accessing my base, period, but so far it's been difficult coming up with a way that works. I really want to be able to focus on getting what I need to complete the level rather than dealing with giant assaults every 45 minutes.

- The skill tree has some merits, but it's super annoying and frustrating to have to waste precious resources crafting a bunch of items you do not need in your fort. Maybe some form of a research to unlock technology system would be better. An invention workshop that consumes raw materials to develop blueprints/new technology?

- The skill tree doesn't have the greatest progression. Some techs you would think are fairly basic, like farming and weaving, are mid-to-late game technologies. Some of the progression (you need alchemy to advance farming?) just seems to be set up to make the game more tedious.

- On a related note, some form of animal husbandry, where you can just put sheep or chickens in a pen or some sort of have then generate wool and eggs would be great. Wool is incredibly important, and can be very time-consuming to obtain when you have to wait for sheep to spawn and send dwarves to the edge of the map to kill them.

- Dwarves' pathing and job handling is often ridiculously poor. A dwarf carries a torch to the very edge of the map, where you need some light added. It runs into a monster. It drops the torch to fight the monster. It picks the torch back up. Does it resume placing the torch? No, it has to walk all the way back to the main base, because while the dwarf was fighting, the base dispatched a different dwarf to install the torch, and that dwarf has only just started its walk.

- Hit a bug where acquiring 999 earth caused all my queued actions on the map to disappear. This happened twice, I ended up crazily just trying to use up earth so it wouldn't hit 999 (wasting a bunch of time by basically having dwarves run around installing earth back walls everywhere) and the bug seems to have gone away, though queued actions are sometimes dropping out, and this may still be to blame. Not certain.

- Spawn rates of flora/mushrooms/crystals and stuff are really high, to the point where trying to mine out a block under a tree took forever because before a dwarf could arrive to mine the block after the tree was cut down, a new tree would grow. Sometimes five or six attempts required. Same issue with crystal and mushroom growth while trying to build a railroad underground.

- There seems to be a max height for tree growth, so my attempts to create a dome of trees to protect my base were unsuccessful.

- It's taking a really long to clear out what seems to be the first level" of the game. 30+ hours."

reviewText:
Do you hate all of the following things:

- Eating food that cannot be prepared in a microwave
- Having meaningful relationships
- Being gainfully employed
- A clean living space
- Going out and doing things
- Responsible adulting

Then this is the game for you!

Take a long nap. Place water and sustenance (preferably something that won't go bad in short order) nearby. Empty out your social calendar.

This game may not seem addictive at first, but that is simply a cunning ruse.  What I'm saying is... I purchased this on a whim during my lunch break.  When I came home, I started it up - intending to play for an hour or so to figure it out.  That figuring-stuff-out process was somewhat frustrating - the in-game tutorial seems complete, but leaves out some of the tips and tricks that make the game really flow (possibly because you're meant to discover them for yourself).

Thankfully, helpful guides and tutorial videos abound (really... use them!).

After that, I remember nothing beyond Craft The World for a period of approximately 10 hours.  By the same time on the next day (after calling in sick to work), I had amassed 20+ hours of play time.

My husband was not impressed, so I bought him a copy.  Problem solved - haven't seen him in days.

Update (12/31/15): After completing the four starting realms and getting all but two of the Achievements, I can still say that I thoroughly enjoy this game.  Looks like the developers have recently added some new content (co-op and pvp, mainly).  I look forward to trying these out!

reviewText:

Overall, I give the game a solid 9/10.

reviewText:
I'm going to say yes on the fact that I bought it on sale for <5$ spent 12 hours playing the first level definately worth the money. The game is not perfect and could use some improvements, but If you can get it on sale buy it before it’s too late.
Cons
- A bit slow at the start of each level but the end seems to fly by making the middle of the play through the most entertaining.
- The tech tree is a bit annoying where you need to waste resources making furniture improvements to craft better armor, a separate tree would be better and streamline the game.
- You cannot sell resources to the shop filling your inventory with junk from previous tech levels.
- Base game speed is grueling, I play at 2x speed to even stay interested in playing for more than 45 min.
- Each level is just a larger harder copy of the previous level, tech does not change the animals and enemies do change with the map but tech progression is non existent.
- The music is not constant and i have found times when the game is completely silent.

Pros
- Beautiful art and sprites.
- First playthrough is highly addictive i.e. 7 hours straight without wanting to stop.
- Excluding the furniture the tech progression is fairly even step to step.

- full tech tree to unlock new objects, craft more powerful items, and make the perfect lava lamp for your Dwarf home
- standard survival mechanics with enemies, hunger, et al

Overall a fun game. Caught it super cheap on the summer sale and don't regret it one bit. Very addicting!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was somewhat hesitant to purchase this game on early access, but having spent a few hours with it I must say the game is very polished and somewhat addicting.

At first blush you may feel like this game belongs on a tablet but after you play for a bit you will quickly realize there is a level of depth in the simulation that makes the game a real challenge at times. The level of detail is outstanding and there is so much to keep you interested and busy in the game I keep coming back for more. It is a great game to have open even if you can't devote 100% attention to it..just set your dwarves to work and you can easily browse the web or talk on the phone. But be careful because once nightfall arrives you may need to turn your focus to fighting off a zerg of enemy mobs.

I am especially enjoying the campaign mode as it provides a good introduction to the crafting system and slowly opens up the world allowing you time to build up your resources. I do wish things were explained a bit better but at this stage in the development the game does a great job of walking you through.

The developers did a great job with this gem of a game and they are very active with providing updates to the game.

I am hopeful the dev's will add a few convenience features and better help text to the game, especially as it relates to building a suitable shelter early on in the game. But overall the game is very enjoyable and playable upon early release.
Don't let the tablet style game graphics turn you off to this game. Give it a try and you won't be sorry!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found this game to be a large time sink. It took me some time to get some of the basic elements at the start of the game (that you start with a totem you can place instead of having to build one from scratch, for example). The end goal of the first level is also difficult to suss out, and I ended up spending a significant amount of time advancing all the tech trees to their maximum when it wasn't strictly necessary to succeed.

Those issues aside, the game is a lot of fun. Whether you treat your dwarves as disposable labourers, or care about them like a family, you'll find things to love about the game. Harvesting resources, building your fortress, and basically showing off your mastery over your environment make this game great fun. The nightly monster raids provide an extra element of danger and amusement, another challenge to overcome.

Probably a good idea to check out a gameplay video first, to make sure it's up your alley, but I for one had a lot of fun with the game.

reviewText:
It's very simple...you NEED this game in your library.

I have absolutely fallen in love with this game. Played around 80 hours at the point of writing this and can easily see myself playing another 80+ hours. It's incredibly addictive.

The dwarves, items, weapons, world(s), enemies, everything in my eyes have been crafted with passion, and it shows!

One thing I will mention if you were thinking about getting this game is you must have patience. Yes, it can (it did for me) take a long time to accumulate resources/items and build a nice big healthy fortress to keep the evil out, but for me personally, found it enjoyable and to a degree challenging keeping on top of it all. Just don't rush anything, have fun, take your time.

If you like building, digging, managing items, fighting enemies, laying traps, crafting items/weapons/armour, cooking, making efficient tunnel networks, decorating your fortress and a whole bunch of other neat stuff...as I said, you need this game.

reviewText:
I'm going to say yes on the fact that I bought it on sale for <5$ spent 12 hours playing the first level definately worth the money. The game is not perfect and could use some improvements, but If you can get it on sale buy it before it’s too late.
Cons
- A bit slow at the start of each level but the end seems to fly by making the middle of the play through the most entertaining.
- The tech tree is a bit annoying where you need to waste resources making furniture improvements to craft better armor, a separate tree would be better and streamline the game.
- You cannot sell resources to the shop filling your inventory with junk from previous tech levels.
- Base game speed is grueling, I play at 2x speed to even stay interested in playing for more than 45 min.
- Each level is just a larger harder copy of the previous level, tech does not change the animals and enemies do change with the map but tech progression is non existent.
- The music is not constant and i have found times when the game is completely silent.

Pros
- Beautiful art and sprites.
- First playthrough is highly addictive i.e. 7 hours straight without wanting to stop.
- Excluding the furniture the tech progression is fairly even step to step.

reviewText:
This game is a blast, and much more challenging than it appears at first glance.  The basic concept is to setup house and work for a group of Dwarves who've just arrived to a new world from beyond a portal.  You'll need to collect materials, craft (weapons, armor, furniture, etc) all while defending them from a relentless onslaught of creatures.  It's a nice combination, which I do reccomend.

Downside:  Once you've finished the first world, the game takes you to a new map with a new biom and new creatures, but the gameplay is essentially the same.  Your crafting starts over and you get all new first level dwarves.   Would be nice if you could keep at least one dude from map to map.

That said, I've played this game for hours and would definintely reccomend it to anyone looking for a nice combination of crafting and psuedo tower defense.

reviewText:
8/10

I love this game. Great looking game with a beautiful artstyle and plenty of depth. The different worlds behave differently, have different animals and natural disasters.

Some things you need to know and take into consideration, before making a buy:

- The game is still being developed - a month ago, we got a new world, that's awesome!
- Since I've bought it, I've experienced the game gets better by each update.

Learn from my mistakes

- You CAN autobuild recipes, but you have to drag'n'drop the first time you craft. Then just choose recipe and hit the green anvil 2 times, to build the recipe. Learned this after 50+ hours of game time and a very sore hand.
- You CAN speed up time. Especially useful in the beginning and between raids. Click the moon-wheel" in the top right corner.

Things I don't care for

- Sound/music
date: it's just "meh" and I ususally turn it of and listen to radio/audiobooks instead. I don't like the dwarf voices at all.\n- Drag'n'drop equipment to dwarfs get's old quick. Especially when you have 12 dwarfs ind your castle.\n- Why do we have to build everything to unlock the recipe-tree? I don't need any pottery or flowerpots right now!"

reviewText:
What happens when you take elements from games like “Dungeon Keeper”, “Terraria”, and “Dwarf Fortress” and roll them into one neat little package?  Why, “Craft The World”, of course!  I discovered this game on Steam’s Early Access and after reading the description, I knew I’d have to give it a whirl.  It’s an interesting mix of different genres, but I found it to be the most reminiscent of “A Game of Dwarves”, even though “Craft The World” has a “Terraria” look and feel about it.  There’s crafting, exploring, minion (Dwarf) management, tower defense, a huge tech tree…for $18.99 (as of 11/24/14), there’s a lot to love.

This takes all the best of Terraria and removes all the obnoxious micromanagement. You don't have to worry about organizing inventories or running back and forth to your base, let your minions do that for you!

This game is still early access, but what is there is well refined and only getting better with every patch. The only gripe I have at this point is simply that it doesn't have quite the depth of content I wish it would have. Hopefully with a few more patches I can scratch even that wish off my list.

Still over 80 hours of play time don't lie. This is a fantastic buy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a minecraft addict who is just not hardcore enough to get over the learning curve of Dwarf Fortress, Craft the World just seems to hit all the addiction points.  Building the first shelter and surviving the first major waves is surprisingly challenging, but it's great fun delving into the crafting game.  The dwarves sometimes do have spotty AI, and it can be hard and a bit frustrating trying to keep them alive near water or big enemies.  However, the player can directly control a dwarf and play it Terriria-style.  Looking for treasures underground or battle enemies in that mode is a lot more reliable and fun.

The game is not without faults, but the charm makes it hard to put down once you start.  Definitely worth picking up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: August 2014
This game is still good and getting better. All three worlds are in and changes are still being made for the better. The graphics are being improved with every patch, and the game feels fulland complete, with each patch just being a cherry on top. With the way the game is now, you can probably get 25 or so hours in a single playthrough, but it is fun to do multiple playthroughs. Worth the money for sure.

This game still has a lot of flaws, given that it is in alpha, but it is incredibly fun non the less. If this game or games in this genre interest you, pick it up while it is cheap, because it is worth it, and only going to get better with more patches. This really does feel like a complete game, just with a few problems, so If you are willing to put up with it (or get it cheap now and wait for more patches so you don't have to pay more when the game is fully released) get it. Worth all of the $15, and even more than that.
Edit:
In the two weeks since I bought this game nearly all of the issues I had with it have been fixed. Dekovir is great about fixing issues soon after they come up, and they are excellent at taking in advice/suggestions from the players. Great company and great game.

reviewText:
Bargain!  Like gnomoria? give this a whirl.

Purchased it, very cheap, 25 hours later I completed the first map (of 3).  I had stayed up till 4am trying to fix something you need to fix before finishing the first level (spoiler protection). No better recommendation. I pulled an all nighter.

Some thoughts:

Good AI on the dwarfs, 90% did what I expected when I expected it.
UI could do with some work.
Grindy tech tree.
Drags a little near the end of the first map, need virtually EVERY resource available to complete the map.
Some resources are finite so dont go crazy making more than you need.
Using the healing pots in combat is a pain ( open equip window, scroll thro all dwarfs to see injuries, rclick health pot, use, repeat up to 3 times per dwarf. Repeat every 10-15 seconds depending on armor equipped).
Satisfying gaining, building and then using tech. (elevators, mine trucks, lightning towers)
Not satisfying realising the tech is pretty obselete with the spells you have... (teleport, fireballs etc)

I managed to snag it 50% off, but it would have been a bargain regardless.
Happy to recommend.

reviewText:
What to say about this one? Well, to start off it is one I recommend whole-heartedly. I enjoy playing CTW a lot. It seems to have the potential to be boring, dig stuff up, find the secret rooms, kill the boss, move on to next level. But it is not boring at all.

So, the story is that you have a dwarf who doesn't even have an axe. Yep, a dwarf without an axe. Mad I say; everyone knows dwarves are born kicking and screaming, beard and all, with axe in hand. Salt and pepper, coffee and cream, mac and cheese, dwarf and axe. Still you have the potential to sort this out pretty soon. Dig up some stone with your little stone knife, cut down a couple of trees and you get to build an axe. Or a pick axe. Or both. But by now, you probably have another dwarf, sans axe of course, and have to kit him out too.

But of course, a stone axe just won't cut it will it? (Sorry, pun intended) You want to move up to iron, steel, silver and eventually to mithril. For all your dwarves. This takes time and patience but it is worth it.

The campaign starts you off in a nice little forest world. Beat this then you move on to an ice world without anything you had before you moved over. But of course you don't move all your team across, just one and you start all over again, this time on a harder world. But you are not done when you finish this world. Desert world is next. Now, the latest update has arrived and, lo, a new world has been added. Underground! With a whole new set of creatures and bad guys to take on and some kind of underground God thing who likes you to leave stuff for it on an altar and if it likes the stuff it will give you useful stuff. I haven't beaten this world yet, only just started it so i can't tell you what happens but all in all a nice addition.

So, get digging / chopping / fishing / smithing and all the other things you need to do to beat this game. I enjoy it and hopefully you will too!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
For 19 euros you get a lot of hours of content.
The game's a bit slow, punishing at times and perhaps repetitive. If you never liked DF's end game, onyl the struggle to it, this game is perfect. There's no end-game economy, just a slow climb to reach the next level.

The game is mostly you sending dwarves to harvest resouce X or attack enemy Y. That's all you can do with them, though you can directly control one at a time (this is VERY inefficient). To aid their escapades, you can craft items (or queue them, if they require skilled dwarvish labour) and equip them or place traps and defences. Or use spells, like portals, to speed up their activities.
Mining, as with all dwarvish games, is a big part.

As you accumulate minerals, food and furniture, you are sometimes assaulted in a heavy siege, or find a loot-riddled dungeon. Ultimately, you wish to gather the plans for a portal and get out of there; it's never safe for long as sieges become stronger and fiercer.

Certainly, it's a simple game. It's not DF compelxcity, but if you just want a simple, slow game that goes perfect with a nice podcast or video, this is great for those! For 19 euros, you get a pretty solid game, with plenty of length and exploring to do.

reviewText:
Craft The World is a game which puts Minecraft, Terraria and SimCity into one big parcel! I think it is a great game for anyone who is looking for a survival gathering game, e.g. Minecraft and Terraria players.

The game itself looks really good. The graphics aren't bad and the animation work.

Good:
+Great gameplay
+Addicting
+Fun for hours
+Graphics are adequate for a game like this
+There are many options for games and you can do a lot of different stuff in the game in order to achieve the recipes.

Bad/Needs fixing:
-The pathing of the characters needs some work
-Some enemies are really hard to defeat without losing any characters
-Can get boring because characters do tasks in a somewhat random order
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you turned Terraria into a simulation/strategy game and added some elements of Starbound, you'd get Craft the World.

Pros
-LOTS of gameplay potential if you're fond of the game mechanics offered (there are 4 stages and I've spend almost 30 hours just on the first one.)
-Randomized worlds mean that your experiences playing will be varied
-Dwarves can each be given their own weapons and items
-Crafting level-up system is interesting and unique
-Tons of items to craft and tons of ways to use them
-A well created base is fairly self-sufficient, you can give your dwarves a bunch of tasks to do, leave for an hour, then come back to find things (usually) going smoothly (as long as you are on an easy level and they have enough food)

Cons
-Dwarf AI is TERRIBLE (caps for emphasis), there are times when they path in the most rediculous ways that waste a lot of time and lead to them taking a lot of extra damage (from falling off ledges, drowning, moving through hazards, ect...)
-Gameplay can get repetative, and it's really annoying to have to start your fort over when you get to a new level
-Leveling up takes forever as you progress which leads to a lot of repetative gameplay.  The big drive for leveling up is getting that extra dwarf at each level to add to your army, but it never feels like you have enough dwarves.  I wish the game gave you more of them to work with as a whole, I feel like the huge buildings I create could/should house a whole legion of dwarves but I'm instead restricted to the 13 I have at level 13
-Fighting often feels anti-climactic, you'll either easily mow down most enemies or get slaughtered by the larger ones (at least until you advance your craft far enough to make better stuff or have more dwarves from leveling up)  There isn't much strategy behind the combat other than making sure you have enough dwarves in an area to swarm the undead during invasions
-Crafting is tedious, the game requires you to put ingredients(click and drag) into slots even though all craftable item recipes are learned from advancing your crafting skill tree.  It only adds a few seconds to gameplay, but having to do it each time you learn a new recipe adds up. (Especially since the game pauses whenever you go into the crafting menu.)
-Moving to a new world causes you to lose all of your research progress.  This is a huge frustration when the portals keep spawning harder and harder monsters and you're struggling to catch up.

Overall
The game offers a lot of gameplay and replayability, especially in the beginning.  And although it may start to feel like a grind later on, you'll still get many solid hours of fun gameplay out of this title.  For the price, it's worth checking out. (And to support the devs in hope they take this system and refine it.)  If you would like more information about this game, I've created some videos showing gameplay...  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pBdcQcppiq0

*Update - So I've gotten to the point where I don't really want to play this game anymore due to the repetative nature.  I'm going to keep the reccomendation just because I easily got my money's worth out of the game, but you may be disappointed by the repetative nature of the late game.  The developer really should have added more unique content to the later levels.

reviewText:
If you turned Terraria into a simulation/strategy game and added some elements of Starbound, you'd get Craft the World.

Pros
-LOTS of gameplay potential if you're fond of the game mechanics offered (there are 4 stages and I've spend almost 30 hours just on the first one.)
-Randomized worlds mean that your experiences playing will be varied
-Dwarves can each be given their own weapons and items
-Crafting level-up system is interesting and unique
-Tons of items to craft and tons of ways to use them
-A well created base is fairly self-sufficient, you can give your dwarves a bunch of tasks to do, leave for an hour, then come back to find things (usually) going smoothly (as long as you are on an easy level and they have enough food)

Cons
-Dwarf AI is TERRIBLE (caps for emphasis), there are times when they path in the most rediculous ways that waste a lot of time and lead to them taking a lot of extra damage (from falling off ledges, drowning, moving through hazards, ect...)
-Gameplay can get repetative, and it's really annoying to have to start your fort over when you get to a new level
-Leveling up takes forever as you progress which leads to a lot of repetative gameplay.  The big drive for leveling up is getting that extra dwarf at each level to add to your army, but it never feels like you have enough dwarves.  I wish the game gave you more of them to work with as a whole, I feel like the huge buildings I create could/should house a whole legion of dwarves but I'm instead restricted to the 13 I have at level 13
-Fighting often feels anti-climactic, you'll either easily mow down most enemies or get slaughtered by the larger ones (at least until you advance your craft far enough to make better stuff or have more dwarves from leveling up)  There isn't much strategy behind the combat other than making sure you have enough dwarves in an area to swarm the undead during invasions
-Crafting is tedious, the game requires you to put ingredients(click and drag) into slots even though all craftable item recipes are learned from advancing your crafting skill tree.  It only adds a few seconds to gameplay, but having to do it each time you learn a new recipe adds up. (Especially since the game pauses whenever you go into the crafting menu.)
-Moving to a new world causes you to lose all of your research progress.  This is a huge frustration when the portals keep spawning harder and harder monsters and you're struggling to catch up.

Overall
The game offers a lot of gameplay and replayability, especially in the beginning.  And although it may start to feel like a grind later on, you'll still get many solid hours of fun gameplay out of this title.  For the price, it's worth checking out. (And to support the devs in hope they take this system and refine it.) reviewText:
Just finished the first world, so I feel a review is now fair to write.  Love this game!  You take charge of a growing squad of dwarves, and give them tasks as needed, in order to make the world a nice place for a clan of dwarves to settle.  But enemies will also come for your kingdom, so take the time to prepare.  You can either just give orders and sit back, or you can get your own hands dirty by taking control of any individual dwarf for certain tasks.

The game has a lot of replay value.  The first campaign, at a fairly normal pace but trying to explore most of the world, took about 25 to 30 hours.  Graphics are simple and cutesy, but still quite pretty and functional for what the game is trying to do.  The crafting tree is robust, with a lot of functional and cosmetic items.  Though, even cosmetic items are functional in a way, given how the dwarves' resting mechanic works.

The only real drawback to this game comes when you gather quite the party of dwarves (over 10).  Then, the dwarven AI individually tends to compete, and they start to derp in frustrating ways.  You'll see 2 or 3 dwarves competing for a single task and getting waylaid on the other side of portals if you don't micromanage certain tasks.  Too, sometimes dwarves will fail their tasks for no apparent reason, or plain not recognize their task.  Fortunately, you can (usually) clear this problem by taking control of a dwarf and/or immediately releasing him.

All in all, the game is fully worth the $20 it was at regular price.  If you catch it on a Steam sale, you'll do even better.  For lovers of simpler real-time strategy, with mining/crafting elements, building, and some battling!

reviewText:
These block/crafting type games tend to look really good but lack substance or look really bad because the devs spend all their time on substance and gamplay NOT THIS ONE. It looks good plays well and is very enjoyable the devs also continue tinkering and improving it.

Whilst I consider this lite" gaming it will challenge you at times and loves to keep the pressure on with waves of enemies coming through a portal every 40 odd minutes. It also likes to mess with my OCD side by using giant worms or dust storms to muck up my dwarf camp (the further you get into the level the less impact these events have.....if you plan right lol)

I have read some other reviews and I agree the dwarfs having pathing issues........lol they are really stupid at times.....but if you really need something done you just take control of a dwarf and do it yourself. Personally I dont bother I just prioritise  the tasks I assign .....like defence first then bury them in chores. You will still have to go looking for one that gets himself stuck or built in every now and then but I just laugh and say dumb dwarfs.

The biggest tip I can give those about to play is don't get to attached to your dwarfs if you let a few die along the way for the greater good of the base you will progress faster plus they are replaced a few minutes later."

reviewText: Sort of a mashup between DF (or its clones like Towns, Gnomoria, Rimworld etc) and sidescrolling explorers like Terraria or it's many clones. reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dOjdW9_Bxmw

Tl;dr;

Not a bad game, but somewhat slow en tedious on the crafting level. Darf AI isn't too great either with them getting stuck or just left clueless often. Multiplayer is a true grief-fest, but what did you want? Fun to play if you can live with its flaws.

----------------

So it's all about crafting a world for you dwarves. They have opened a portal which only had the power to transport 1 brave pioneer into your playfield and depend on your guidance to prosper and thrive. That is, if you can hold off the forces of evil that come out every night and every 45 minutes (the Devil sure is punctual).

To do so you need to gather resources by clicking on them. After that your eager dwarves will mine or hack away and carry the stuff back to the stockpile where it can be used to craft new items/base decorations/fortifications/food/...

Sadly not all dwarves are born with an Einstein level intellect so you will be wondering why 1 of them (let's call him Toby) is always doing the exact opposite of what you want. Be prepared to bail Toby out a lot with portals, scaffolding and ladders.

Building the actual shelter is pretty basic and not too refreshing. The only real notable thing is the aura of the Totem". The more comfort you give the dwarves
date: the larges their base will become. Which in turn gives you more space for more dwarves.\n\nYou get new darves by leveling up through crafting
recommended: completing tasks and combat. It somehow makes it feel too much like a mobile game by doing this
hoursPlayed: but then again every other comparable game does it... Leveling is pretty fast in the beginning but slows down incredibly after lvl 10
voteText:
however the monster waves don't.

So you day to day management will be:

-  gather resources
- craft what you need for new technologies
- give dwarves new items
- expand base

Sounds like a lot of fun? Well it is in the beginning... but after a while you need to craft 100 fancy chairs just to be able to pass on to Steel armour. It makes no sense to me
helpfulPercent: uses up a lot of resources and especially slows things down dramatically. The first "easy" world will take quite a while to complete
votesHelpful: even with cheats...\n\nAnd then there's multiplayer... for the love of God or Buddha or whoever you wish to believe in
votesTotal: do it with friends or alone. Chances are random players will screw you over beyond belief sending you right back to your tedious crafting without any reward whatsoever.\n\nSo all in all I want to really like the game for its ideas and just because I love the genre
votesFunny: but I'm stuck just barely liking it because some things can be too frustrating. If you can get it on a decent sale then don't doubt

reviewText:
I played this game on a friend's computer earlier in the year and whilst it was ultimately very enjoyable it was also deeply frustrating due to the awful AI. So almost a year later when I found the game on sale I thought it must be worth it now - it must have improved.

However it seems like the only real change is the addition of multiplayer which just seems like a way of making the dodgy dwarf AI even more frustrating to deal with. There is nothing more annoying than watching a dwarf repeatedly attempt to climb up a massive wall and repeatedly fall until they gradually kill themselves all for the sake of recovering a leaf that had fallen to the bottom of a long forgotten pit on the other side of the map.

In the early stages of the game this problem is hampered by wood shortages so you cannot build ladders to prevent it or food tables, beds and a shelter to even heal them back up after. In the late game this problem results in spending significant amounts of time shoring up the map to stop the little morons killing themselves doing pointless things. Both are annoying.

If it was my first playthrough I'd have tolerated it I guess but having already done all of this before and having already gone through all the tedious late game grinding each stage involves I found myself just wanting to give up and refund it after twenty minutes. So not a lot of replay value then...

reviewText:
6.5/10; only buy on sale.

Craft the World tries to be a more polished mix of Dungeon Keeper, Terraria, and Dwarf Fortress.  Sounds like an amazing idea, but the reputation and success of those games makes for extremely large shoes to fill.  Now, while CtW is a decently fun game, it's just not deep enough to appeal to fans of the games which it is based upon.

It has the 2d construction and mining that Terraria has, but none of the different worlds are nearly as epic" as the world made in Terraria.  Terrarra had a significant "Metroidvania" aspect in its crafting and looting that expanded the player's exploration options once they've found the right materials.  CtW tries to do this in the form of a techtree
date: but it just feels grindy and arbitrary compared to Terraria's more subtle systems.  The different biomes from Terraria instead exist as separate maps in CtW
recommended: making the scope of each world much smaller despite the larger number of builders.   For example
hoursPlayed: one of the funnest aspects of Terraria was that digging could get you to run into old sunken ships
voteText: mushroom worlds
helpfulPercent: and demonic fortresses.  In CtW
votesTotal: some insects
votesFunny: and maybe a vampire.  The game's pace is much slower as well
commentsCount: which makes it feel like a slog through a shallow pit compared to Terraria.\n\nFew games can match the complexity and deepness of Dwarf Fortress
column16: but CtW doesn't even begin to graze the surface.  Dwarves in CtW are born with innate specializations and can train and equip for more
column17: but they can't ever be assigned specific tasks.  There is a "trader
column18: but he's more like a regular RPG vendor and there is no diplomacy.  The challenge from DF is also unlikely to be found.  The game, with its combined slow pacing and simplicity, just doesn't have the same losing is fun!" appeal that Dwarf Fortress does
column19: and you have to really mess up badly to even begin to replicate experiences from that game.\n\nSo why the recommendation?  Well
column20: I cannot pretend that any game worse than DF or Terraria is a bad game.  I had some fun playing CtW
column21: thanks to the graphics and polish.  Making my dwarves upgrade to defend against increasingly threatening invasions was fun.  I'm just not sure who to recommend it to; fans of Dwarf Fortress will find it way too simplistic
column22: and fans of Terraria would want a more diverse world to explore.  Maybe to people who've played neither and are interested in this sort of game
column23: but why?  DF is free and Terraria is 1/5 the price.\n\nBottom line: Craft the World is a decently fun game but does not nearly match the epicness and complexity of the games it is based on.  Buy it on sale and don't expect to be blown away."

reviewText: One of the most frustrating games I have ever played.  I can understand a game where your controlable units are meant to be careless and goofy, but this is far beyond that.  The AI is ATROCIOUS.  To the point where crafting even the most simple structures becomes a frustrating time sink of placing ladders, then removing ladders, then one of your dwarves gets attacked so EVERY SINGLE DWARF drops what they're doing to help, then they procede to pick up all the items they dropped and, instead of completing their original task, returning said items to base before having someone else entirely go now pick up the items, then oops one of your dwarves gets attacked...\n\nOver it.  Do not recommend.

reviewText:
Craft the World is worth buying if you're looking for a 2D sandbox game that feels like terraria and all the others, but you command a group of dwarves instead of your own character. Three campaign levels lasting 15 hours each, and tons of replayability with randomly generated worlds and settings you can change with custom games. The dwarves may not be the smartest and will probably make you want to yell at them at times, but it is still a nice game.

A quick look into the gameplay of Craft the World:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ken2zivJPxk

You need to defend your dwarves against waves of enemies, build them a proper shelter and progress technologicaly to better everything. :P

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had my eye on this game for many months before I finally caved and bought it. It happily kept me up until 5am and swallowed my Sunday entirely - this game is addictive!

Pros:
++ Fun and addictive
+ Solid balance between micro and macro
+ Adorable

Cons:
--- No way to alter game speed. This can make the game feel stagnant and slow at times.
- Full screen only, which crashes local video players so you can't watch a video while playing.
- No sense of purpose/long term goals, yet there is a second world to unlock so there is indeed a goal.

Verdict:
If this *looks* like your kind of game, it probably *is* your kind of game, and is worth $15.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Megomaniacal Gnomes wanted:    Finally, control ALL the people on your Terraria server.  Why? Because they don't know wtf they're doing.  Build your very own fortress of DOOM.  Prepare to be ravaged by goblins.  Endless value & replay await.  Ever since Dwarf Fortress repeatedly made me it's b!tch, I've been dreaming of a game like this: easy enough to let me progress a bit further, feel somewhat accomplished a little more each time, *THEN* slaughter my gnomes, raid my base, raze my village, & crush my dreams of crafting the world.
TD, Sandbox, RTS, RPG elements - 97/100

I love this game for what it is, & embrace the stoogely behavior of the gnomes as hilarious!  Thanks to the ingenious toggle system that allows the player to possess any of their minions, there is no excuse for failure here save your own lack of planning & skill.  Relax & enjoy your series of defeats as you learn the ways of the craft.  Think of each as another defeated exploration party on your way to winning.  There is a restart level button for a reason.  Compared to the impossible difficultly of Dwarf Fortress, this is sheer bliss, a fun game for beginners.   Don't be fooled!  Craft the World becomes fiendish & deceptive.  Enemies are clever...  perhaps too clever.  Most will get through th efirst few waves of the dead just to be smashed by invading gobs.  Fortify yourselves, friends, lest they feast on gnome flesh this night.

Craft the World" has set a new standard and will inevitably go down in gaming history alongside the other clever hybrids of this neo-2D-Terrarian-sandbox phenomenon."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After completing the first level, I decided to share my thoughts about the game.

Lets start with the good:

The world is fun to interact with. Instead of directly modifying it as in other games, you only indicate what needs to be done, and the dwarfs take care of the rest. It is fun to watch the clumsy dwarfs doing their job. Digging underground tunnels, building bridges, houses, and defensive walls. You need to explore the world to find needed resources. You start with cutting trees, but soon create long underground tunnels in search for rare minerals. You can help your dwarfs by equipping them with better tools, weapons and armor. From time to time, you get attacked by an army of skeletons and monsters. It creates the feeling of urgency, keeping you motivated to keep exploring and improving your defenses. One of your first tasks will be to build a shelter, a place where your dwarfs can replenish their energy, and defend against monsters. This 'world' part of the game is fantastic: 10/10.

Lets continue with the bad:

In order to progress in the game you will need to craft items. This is where the fun gets replaced by boring, and tiresome activity.
In order to craft an item, you first have to display the crafting interface. This will show you a 3x3 grid where you have to place the components and click 'Craft' to finish. Each component needs to be individually placed in the grid, by dragging it from its location in the inventory. The inventory has a number of tabs, and an additional click is required to find the component.
This tedious process brings absolutely nothing to the game. It is boring, interrupts the game flow (the game stops during crafting), and it feels more like work than play. It is extremely annoying when playing on the laptop with just a touchpad.

A click-fest as another reviewer called it. I will call it a carpal-syndrome simulator. For example to craft a Bucket (a rather simple item) you need to click your mouse button 12 times (4 times drag-drop). And you will be doing it a lot. Every item in the game needs to be crafted, and in order to progress through the crafting tree, you will be even crafting items you don't need. The 'crafting' part of the game is simply not fun: 0/10.

Unfortunately I can't recommend the game in the current state. Not with the boring drag-drop spreadsheet you will be forced to deal with half the time.  While still in the 'Early Access' state, the game has enormous potential, but I recommend waiting before buying it. Keep it in your wishlist instead.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of Dungeon Keeper, Terraria and Dwarf Fortress then this game is for you.
I got this way back and forgot i even had it after i moved, but in the last week i have rediscovered this gem and have been losing sleep just to play....... It's really a fun game, i love the way you can build and defend and destroy everything, the crafting, and even take control of a specific dwarf.
This said, the game has a few bugs here and there, but what game doesn't? I'm sure it'll be worked out eventually...they always are.
I highly recommend this game to any and everyone. Lose yourself in this world .........and Craft your world the way you want to.

reviewText:
SEX!

Huzah!  Now I have your attention.

As far as God-simulators go, this game is pretty awesome.  The game has a surprising amount of depth and a creative sandbox mode once you complete the 3 level campaign which adds to the fun.  The campaign consists of 3 levels: first is a small forest setting, the second is a medium sized snow setting, and the last is a large desert, each getting more difficult to pass.  Don't be fooled by the few levels though, each one has taken me upwards of 10 hours each to finish.

Over the course of a game, you have to start with nothing much like other creation games such as Minecraft, and build your way up from nothing by gathering everything from dirty to iron, gold, and eventually Mithril.  Using these gathered resources, you traverse a large tech tree, each category allowing you to build more items ranging from decoration for your home to weapons and armor.

The game will pique your interest quick and hold your attention for a long time.  With that said, once you beat the campaign and do a sandbox mode or two, you start to notice and exploit things like how to efficiently mine, find gold or skill books, and how to cheese the invading zombies (I will not reveal that here.)  Once this happens, you (or at least I did) will get bored quickly.  The novelty for me wore off literally halfway through a game one day, and I just quit.

The Good:

1-Great crafting system
2-Challenging combat (not at first, but the longer you stay in game, the more enemies come out to ransack you)
3-very fun spellunking system
4-hours upon hours of fun per level
5-quests give you both direction and reward

The Bad:
1-Once you've discovered combat and mining exploits, the game loses most of its fun and challenge
2-Even the largest maps are pretty small, taking maybe only 25% more time to finish than the smallest
3-Enemy waves happen only once every 50 minutes (25 minutes if you have the game speed set to 2x)
4-weapon and armor improvements are WAY down the tech tree, so you have inferior gear against large waves if you dont move fast

All in all, the game is a great way to burn a lot of hours, especially for how cheap it is.  being under $20 means that as long as you enjoy it for at least 10 hours, it was well worth it, and I promise you will get a lot more than that out of it.
voteText: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful 18 people found this review funny

reviewText: Pros: good atmosphere, a variety of enemies and crafting.\nCons: the AI is simply intolerable disgusting, your dwarves will always be blunt, stuck somewhere, die like idiots. During the battle with the most powerful monster in the game, a couple of gnomes just ignored him and started to cut the vines next to it (do it automatically), when you get tired with AI, you will encounter the second problem: what, in fact, to do? And there is nothing. No plot, all you have to do - just move up the scientific tree, then build a portal to a new world and all over again, with the passage of one of the world took me 16 hours, on the second I just got bored.\nIt pains me to play it.

reviewText: Buying a game that you have neither seen nor heard of is a lot like gambling. Sometimes it pays off and you get hours of fun out of it, sometimes you are dealt a bad hand. This time was the latter for me. As much as I want to like this game, it suffers from a tremendously bad UI that is clunky and not very intuitive. I had to keep replaying the tutorial because I simply couldn't wrap my head around the UI. I feel like it has a steeper learning curve than the game itself. Browsing the forums, I see others have had the same complaint and have requested everything from minor changes to a complete overhaul of the UI, and the developer's response has basically been “deal with it”. So the only hope would be for a UI mod developed by a third party. Maybe if/when that happens, I will revisit this game, but for now, it has been uninstalled and moved into my “Bad Games” category.

reviewText:
Craft the World is a very fun and addicting simulation game. You start off the game with one dwarf, a storage location and a shop to buy things. There is also technology tree where you have to complete a number of items crafted to reach the next tier. You use your dwarf to locate the items required, which could be a plant, an animal or a mineral. When you start crafting you will gain experience points to reach the next level. At each new level you gain one new dwarf to help with your city.

The game does have a day and night rotation. During the night zombies, skeletons and other foul beasts will show up in an attempt to destroy your creation. When you slay them you will get some experience points and they will drop some loot. There will also be goblins that try to move in randomly during the day.

The interface is very easy to use. You can drag the items you crafted into a tool bar, click it again to select it and then place them on the map. The crafting is done by dragging items into one of nine boxes. Depending on what item you place in which box you'll create an item. This might seem cumbersome at first, but the first time you make a mistake and discover an item you don't have the instructions for, you'll be happy it was made that way.

I played the game at an easy setting to get use to it and have some fun. There are ways to make it more challenging. I set it so that when a dwarf dies he later respawns, but you can set it so that it is a permanent death.

If you are into simulaiton games where you get to build homes, this is the game for you.

Better control & selection of them is deffo required - maybe a command bar on the selected unit cus direct control of a Dwarf as its problems. Game crashes are common at the time of this review. However, its got great potential & is quite entertaining & can be addictive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy cow this game is addicting. I usually try to stay away from Early Access games but I picked this up when it was on sale and I don't regret it. Once I start, it's hard to stop. Lots of progression and things to do. You command dwarves to cut down trees, dig for minerals, fight monsters, hunt animals, defend off regular waves of enemies, cook food for your army, build armor and weapons, and more.

Not everyone's type of game, if you're expecting something like Terraria or Starbound then you're not gonna get it here. This is a different experience for people who like managing multiple individual units and completing a lot of tasks.

reviewText: This game is a fun little game until you take into account that every few weeks it will randomly lose your saved progress forcing you to restart at the beginning of level one. This has happened to me multiple times now and I therefore cannot recommend this game to anyone. Perhaps I will adjust that view point if they return my saved game to me or at least unlock sandbox mode that allows you to choose a level to play at instead of forcing you to clear all preceding levels over and over again since they cannot keep saved data. There is also no way to do a manual save or to reload from backed up data. Overall that makes the game frustrating to the point of being unplayable. Fix that and it would easily be one of my top ten games.

reviewText:
*This is a casual game with no loss condition. The only theoretical threat comes from night-time hordes of monsters, but that's a farce. Assuming they successfully breach your defenses, they just stand there in the main hall, waiting for morning to come (at which time they burn to ashes like vampires), while all your critically injured dwarves sleep and heal somewhere else.

*The crafting system for Craft The World is a textbook example of a developer ripping a system off from another game without actually understanding its point. In Minecraft, you get a 9 square grid where you can place ingredients because you are meant to actually guess and experiment with recipes. In Craft the World, the recipes are *given to you* as you advance down a tech tree, but the game still expects you to laboriously drag ingredient by ingredient to the grid every time you want to craft something. Why can't I just select the item and quantity I want and be done about it???

*Most techs range from mildly useful to entirely cosmetical, but you are still required to craft several items from each to unlock the next, which results in a lumbering grind.

*There are no female dwarves and population does not increase the way... one would expect. Instead, new dwarves magically teleport in when you reach tech tree milestones. There's no demographical simulation at all; this ain't no Dwarf Fortress.

*You have to manually reposition all traps after every night-time invasion attempt by the undead horde. But as I said, you might not even bother, as nothing of consequence actually happens if they get through.

*The sound effects are exaggerated, repetitive and get on your nerves. From non-stop loud snoring to the cheesiest battlecries, your ears don't get 10 seconds of respite.

reviewText:
I've played Craft The World twice, in two sittings, the two of them equal the playtime you see with this review.
What the hell was I doing? Why is this review negative?
I got roped in, I got sucker-punched with the all too psychologically powerful allure of mobile-game design.
I understand that phrase is considered an ill one in the gaming community, it smacks of tedium, tasks drawn out to the most painful extent possible, and constant, tiny, new goals that move you a modicum forward for dozens of minutes of effort.

That's really what it is. I mean, what's here is done fairly well.

Your dwarves are automated little cretins with terrible AI who go out, collect resources that you assign them to collect, build what you want them to build, and come back to sleep in their shelter when their health is low, or eat food after they've exerted themselves and built up some of them good old munchies. The game works, it's relatively bug free (I had one crash, and sometimes dwarves get stuck trying to get out of water, that's about it), the mechanics are fluid, and the game is generally competent. Whoopee.
At first it's impossibly addictive. This game is deceptively simple, and what I mean by that is that there's a great illusion here of this game having a lot to it at first, you look at the fairly large tech tree, the needs and behaviors of your dwarves, the monster waves with the promise of tower defense" style strategy
date: and mechanics like farms and being able to husband animals in them.\n\nIt's fairly cool at first look
recommended: but everything here is surface level. There's very little automation of tasks
hoursPlayed: you can't instruct your dwarves to automatically sheer sheep
voteText: or plant
helpfulPercent: harvest
votesTotal: or automatically build and rebuild structures. I'm kind of stretching here
votesFunny: but with games of this type
commentsCount: I expect a certain amount of ease of use features to make it more fluid to play
column16: but like I said
column17: this is a mobile-style game
column18: meaning they WANT you to perform as many actions as possible to drag out the playtime.\nThat basically means doing every little simple thing takes a very large amount of button presses
column19: if you want to craft something
column20: you first have to manually arrange the recipe yourself
column21: then craft it
column22: then drag it to a hot bar
column23: then place it
column24: then wait for your dwarves to put it down
column25: after they've dropped it off at the stockpile
column27: and finally gotten on their way.\n\nIt's that kind of maddening tedium that somehow becomes addictive for a brief period of time
column28: and in my tiredness and desire for something completely mindless to distract me it did its job
column29: but when I finally finished the first level

but somehow I slogged through this game twice a year apart.

reviewText:
The Good and Bad of Craft the World:
Good:
-Nice smooth combo-nation of building, mining, crafting, fighting and other things.
-Massive crafting tree.
-Graphics-May not be PS4 or Xbox1 quality, or Wii U HD, but still charming.
-Good use of spells
-Multiple worlds.
-Music is fantastic
Bad:
-Dwarf AI is horrible-Dwarfs will try to pick items up when monsters are near the items, and will still go to pick up items that used to be there.
-Inconsistences with the crafting tree and other worlds-On the ice world, the game wanted me to research fishing, even though there were no fish in that world.
-No easy and quick way to get mana back in the early game-(expect leveling up); mana potions come in late midgame.
-Frustrating moments when you need better armor or wepons, but are forced to work on useless things.
Notes:
-One world takes a long time; spent 25 hours in all to complete the first world.

reviewText:
Whimsical. Initially it was interesting (figuring out the system, telling the dwarves where to defend / explore / dig). Overall, however, the game doesn't scale well. It is fun at first, but after getting a sense for how to play, there aren't many choices or challenges.

Limited materials make construction of many of the objects incredibly difficult.
Dwarf AI is pretty stupid -- they don't get in mine carts, dropping objects down deep shafts, prioritizing distance objects, poorly engaging creatures, making long trips just to deliver one torch, etc. It could be managed...it just isn't fun to manage.
Crafting system is slow -- the constant moving of objects to craft something new gets old. (And yes, this is using the quick craft" system.)
It is hard to manage once the tunnel system gets large. Mine carts just don't work well enough to make a smoothly flowing system -- even if you have enough iron to make that much track.
Some of the above can be fixed by using the 2x game speed...but there still aren't that many choices to be made."

This game is pretty awesome.

reviewText:
After spending a long time playing Minecraft and Terraria, I started looking for a new game with similar playing experience and that would hook me in just like those ones. Craft The World seemed to do just that, and once I started playing I found myself sucked in and spending long hours immersed, at least until I completed the first world.

The game is very enjoyable to play, easy and intuitive to learn. It’s fun to command around your army of cute little dumb dwarfs. And dumb they are, sometimes amusing you with their complete goofiness and sometimes testing your patience to the limit, as they so often seem to refuse collaboration. They have a persistent tendency of being in the wrong place. Command your dwarfs to build something, and you can be sure all other idle dwarfs will run to that same spot and stand there doing nothing, just hampering the dwarf who is actually trying to do the building. Relax your attention for a moment, and the dwarves may wander off getting lost into caves or falling down to their deaths into pits full of critters.

All this fun will last you through the first world though, as you will have to start from scratch once you beat the first world and start the second one. All the long hours you spent grinding through the tech tree, collecting resources, upgrading and training your dwarfs will all be lost once you make it through the portal to the next world.

This is a major drawback of this game, as it gives you little reason to keep on playing after the first world. It’s frustrating to have to start over, and not being able to keep your dwarves and tech upgrades. I don’t mind arriving at a new world to build and explore, but starting everything all over from point zero with one dwarf and no tech was enough for me to put the game down for good.

Another part of the game mechanics that makes little sense is the huge tech tree you have to work through in order to get access to better equipment. Many of the items you are forced to craft in order to advance are completely useless (mirrors, decorative items, columns, statues, gargoyles...). These useless items should not be mandatory.

It would also be nice to be able to assign individual tasks to a dwarf or group of dwarves, as the current game only allows tasks to be assigned collectively. This task assignment is not always efficient – sometimes a dwarf standing right next to a assigned task will do nothing while another dwarf will come from far away to complete that task.

I can say without any doubt that I enjoyed playing this game and that the 30 hours+ spent to finish the first world were worth the money I paid for it, but I wish there had been a way to continue the game without losing everything I conquered.

Maybe the developers will correct these issues in a future update, as it has been a major source of complaint among players.

reviewText:
Great game with a fun concept. Similar to games like Terraria but with less direct control but it adds a whole new dynamic by managing a group rather than a single person. You can still take control of a single character or let them run.

Occasionally frustrating when they won't follow commands due to fatigue that's vaguely indicated so often you have no idea why they aren't working. But it's something that's quickly overlooked as a flaw.

Would be nice if they could speed up a bit, once they get deep underground it takes a very long time to transport supplies and building additional supply points takes a while so once you hit a certain point it gets really mundane for a while until you jump up to the next tech.

Otherwise a great game. I would give it a 8/10

reviewText:
9/10

Excellent game.  If you like survival-craft games, this is a nice spin on that!

Pros
- Just very well polished
- Challenging
- Freedom in how you build your defenses up and survive
- The dwarves are cool and being able to gear them up is very fun
- Lots of items to be crafted
- Graphics are very pleasant to look at

Cons
-Not multiplayer.  Not sure how it could be done, but would be nice to play with friends
-Could use more levels and variety of maps.  The levels are randomly generated though which helps with replayability.
-Finite number of resources.  Could use more ways to replenish resources like iron, etc.  There are ways to do this, but would be nice to know you could try to survive forever on one map.

reviewText: Really enjoyed the crafting and building system, however the pacing of the game feels very off. Having to completely max out every tier in the crafting process in order to advance between worlds becomes very grindy. This is a 10+ hour process with little variety between worlds save a few themed block recipes, e.g. ice tables on the snow world. I believe the game would be better to have the crafting tree maxed out over the course of several worlds, using new ores, etc.\n\nThe game is still fun and worth the price.

reviewText: I very highly recommend this game. I won't go into great detail as others already have but I must say that I find the game challenging and entertaining. After the first world I feel like the challenge really ramps up. As others have stated before, Even midway through the first world will become increasingly more difficult as you struggle for resources. A HUGE help is I discovered you can put items in the crafting window to break them down for some components back and I feel not pointing this out in an extremely obvious fashion is a major oversight. Breaking down old equipment is very helpful but I do hope the developers make it so ALL crafted items can be broken down for base components.\n\nAlso if the developers can add more content for the other worlds that would be a large incentive to play them as the first world can be difficult enough and the rest just get harder. With no new unlockables for the later stages it feels like I should just keep replaying the first level. PLEASE ADD MORE CONTENT!!!! Maybe add rare equipment like boots of speed, backpack of holding, flaming sword of doom, etc?

reviewText:
Ever sat down at your computer and had the overwhelming urge to micromanage nomadic dwarves into a powerful, sophisticated Gimly-esque beings? I think we can safely assume EVERYONE has had this yearning at least once in their adult life. Like rain to a desert, nay, like a backscratcher to a rashy bottom finally a game to sait our buring desire.

Seriously though. This dwarven ant-farm is the perfect screen saver to have running while you study, work or do house chores. Just come back to build, reselect resources to gather and defend your keep against the various undead that swarm periodically. Each dwarf is complete with his own name and randomly selected skill. It is hard not to get attached to these bearded tomagochis.

I have and will continue to recommend this game to anyone that looks NEAR my direction.

reviewText: I'm usually very iffy when it comes to crafting games but this one blew me away. Instead of being a single person digging holes and exploring, you start out with one dwarf who carries out simple tasks like chopping down trees, collecting food, mining, etc. You get more dwarves as the game progresses and you level up. You gain experience from every little action you take but the majority of it will come from fighting. Every night, monsters come out and will try to kill off your dwarves. It's usually not very threatening but there's a constant countdown for a huge wave of monsters that gets bigger and more dangerous as time progresses so you have to make sure you're working towards better gear and shelter fast enough to survive. This is where the tower defense mechanic comes into play. You can build traps and other obstacles to either thin out the herd or slow them down while your dwarves attack from safety. You win by exploring the depths of the land and fighting the bosses" for portal keys. Once you've collected the portal keys
date: you can complete the level at your leisure.\n\nOther than the story missions
recommended: you can also set up custom games and that's pretty much all I do now. You choose the size of the map
hoursPlayed: the weather frequency
voteText: the difficulty
helpfulPercent: and the biome. You can choose from either a forest
votesTotal: or desert area and each one plays radically different. The forest is the easiest one with lots of trees and other vegetation. The snow area is a bit more difficult because you have to melt ice to gain water and snowfall can make the terrain a bit harder to traverse if you don't clear it out frequently. Finally
votesFunny: the desert is the hardest of them all with less trees and berries than the other maps and the constant threat of sandstorms grabbing dwarves and scattering around items.\n\nIn short
commentsCount: it's a very fun crafting game that does some things a little differently while still keeping the basic jist of other crafting games."

reviewText: when I first launched it I liked it, but I kept re-making levels because it took me some time to find the difficultly I liked. The game looks really good and it is quite fun for the first hour or so.

The problem comes when you realize you have to research the whole frigging technology tree, through tons of utterly useless technologies making the first level of the game beatable in 12+ EXTREMELY boring hours.

I honestly wouldn't suggest buying this game.

reviewText:
*Update*

So I'm back in this game even though my save game was corrupted months ago because I noticed there's a new update out and I started over.

The game still has issues and is ridiculously slow at some points as it has been but I've seen a lot of improvements.

Turns out the programmers did not attempt to sell early and cash on / abandon their software after all, they keep working on it and that's something that you don't see too often. I should however mention that this version feels like an actual release and not the one that was released half a year ago.

The game is the best at base building and managing multiple characters, although some shortfalls when it comes to AI and battles. If they were to add some speed in the game it would be perfect.

If my save gets corrupted this time I'm quitting for good.

I'm done.

I have over 300 hours in this game, so it's evident that I really enjoy playing it.

The thing that's making me walk away is the fact that I can have over 80 hours into a level and my system will blue screen and my entire save is gone, done, kaput. Great game, tons of fun.  Frustrating as !@#$ when you lose your progress.

reviewText:
Unfortunately this game is too slow to be interesting. It also has a lot of mobile tendencies that do not translate to the PC.

My main gripe is that you need to drag recipe ingredients over the first time to craft. It's needlessly slow and once your ingredients list gets a lot larger it's harder to find them.

I say skip it entirely as this is probably not the game you're looking for. It has a lot of good ideas that just fall flat.

reviewText:
I bought this game when it was still in its early stages of development, almost a year ago. The game was fun back then, but it clearly needed a lot more work put into it, so I left it for a while and decided to come back to it once it had been updated a bit.

Almost a year on, I decided to give the game another blast and see what had changed. The answer to that was, not a lot!

It's a very slow paced game where you need to craft various items from basic house furnishings, to weapons and equipment. The recipes need more and more materials to create them, so you need to venture deep into the earth and explore the wild around you to find them. The problem is, this slow pace is almost halted to a crawl as the AI of the dwarves is absurd!

The dwarves often stand there path finding" when they are stood in the middle of an open area
date: with nothing around them which could be considered an obstacle. Often even a simple jump takes 20 seconds of calculations to work out how to do it.\n\nI revealed an area with some pretty tough monsters in it. A guardian whom can summon skeletons and is only vulnerable to mithril (which will take you some time to research due to the afore mentioned problems). After realising he was too tough
recommended: I cancelled my command to attack him and wanted my dwarves to go back to what they were doing. The problem was
hoursPlayed: once I had cancelled the command
voteText: this did NOTHING to stop my dwarves repeatedly running and trying to attack the Guardian. Even using the "call to fortress" feature was useless as that would cause them to stay in one place and do nothing
helpfulPercent: then once I cancelled this order
votesHelpful: they would run straight back to the Guardian to try and kill him!\n\nIn the end my dwarf I had skilled up to be my main warrior was killed due to his own (and the games) stupidity. After this
votesTotal: I decided that the time and effort I put into getting to where I did had been wasted.\n\nI would not reccommend this game unless the developers revamped the entire AI system and made the game actually playable. Until then
votesFunny: it's not worth £14! I would pay maybe £3 for this game
commentsCount: but would much rather see it offered as a flash game on some website for free!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Craft The World is ownly bound to get better.  There are so many more features in this game than they let me know of!  The game seems to intelligently progress in difficulty and is constantly keeping me on my toes, but not ruining the experience.  This game is like Lemmings and Terraria put together.  I like Dwarf Fortress, but we can't compare apples to oranges, folks.

The fun is in the unique management that you have to endure.  There is no number crunching of taxes or balancing of peasant population to that of the warriors...  The management is in the making sure your work gets done before nightfall, keep your dwarves fed, provide a safe work environment (yes, they can slip, trip, drown, and fall to their deaths), provide shelter, and then get to your exploring.

To top it off, the game is visually enjoyable.  It is asthetically color balanced and the animations are reminicent of Monty Python's cartoon shorts.

I love it!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I reccomend this game but only in some circumstances.

It's a fine game, its well made, the art is nice, graphics are vibrant and the gameplay and crafting systems are pretty in depth. The crafting system is especially well made and is probably the highlight. I've seen some people say its hard to control the Dwarfs and it is and isn't at the same time. Early game its easy to get your dwarfs moving in one direction. Late game once you get vast chasms of mines and tunnels you'll be tearing your hair out when goblins suddenly spawn next to your house while all your dwarfs but 2 or 3 are away in the tunnels. There are some useful presets you can give to your dwarfs to perform certain jobs, the lite RPG elements are neat and give serious benefits to highly leveld dwarfs for their jobs but it becomes damn near impossible to keep track of everything and keep all your dwarfs on the same page after your population hits 20 or 30.

The crafting is neat. You start you gathering resources and clearing tunnels and land. You develop a nice plot to place a house on and keep your dwarfs slept and fed and then you go from there progressively upgrading and improving your tools, armor, weapons and workbenches. The crafting system has a fairly deep system but it still didn't seem deep enough to keep me interested late game. After so long it became more of a stalemate and i couldn't keep up nor could i dig far enough and build enough ladders to get to the best ores. At this point i lost interest since i was more or less in a slogging grind and was making little to no progress. To some that may be part of the fun, and it is for me usually, but the crafting system wasn't deep enough to keep me grinding. Since crafting is one of the main, if not the main, selling points of this game that can be a hit or miss depending on who you are or what you like. I'd recommend it to people who can get this game on the cheap and enjoy cartoony games with lots of charm and a neat little twist on the craft/survive genre.

Its got a bit of Minecraft, Terraria and a bit of RTS-RPG like Warcraft 3. It has good charm from your dwarfs and some of the enemies you battle. It has vibrant colors with clean, well made graphics that fit the atmosphere and gameplay perfectly. And finally the sound design and quality are pretty top notch for an indie game or Mobile port (not sure if this is a mobile port but it seems like one).

Pros
-Vibrant Colors and Graphics. Very clean and pretty.
-Nice sounds and music. Helps keep the charm of the game up during play.
-Charm. This game has a good amount of charm, atleast to me.
-RPG elements. It has several layers and types of RPG elements
-Crafting system. Its fairly easy to understand, a bit convoluted but has decent depth.
-RTS elements with individual characters having their own equipment slots.
-Many different jobs and noticable changes to productivity from job skills leveling up.

Cons
-Turns into a grind late game.
-Crafting system wasn't deep enough to keep me interested late game or long term.
-Some enemies seem very annoying, the goblins especially.
-The game is good in many different facets but doesn't really excell at any one in specific.
-Somewhat convoluted design to mages and some crafting recipes.
-A slight learning curve, especially for those new to the genre.
-Some of the items and furniture seem useless and arbitrary.

Thats about it. Its good little game. I feel it was worth the price. I think i payed $7.50 or $10 for it and i got a nice, enjoyable 10 hours out of it. I'll probably come back a few months down the line to give it another play through because the game does have a lot of charm to me despite its flaws. Its a, for the most part, technically solid game that was better than i'd expected. I think it deserves a buy if you're into Terraria/Starcraft, Minecraft and other games of that ilk. I wouldn't reccomend it on its RPG-RTS elements alone but they blend together well with the survival/craft elements to make a rather enjoyable and worthwhile game, even if its worth wasn't that long for this one guy.
