reviewText:
This game has me quite torn. It has so much potential to be a really awesome game but just a few things hold it back, I think.

I really like the base mechanics of the game. You don't control your people individually, but rather tell them what to do and they'll get to it eventually. This can lead to annoyance as things can become high priority to you and your people continue to do the other 'housekeeping' tasks you've set. I could be wrong, but as far as I know, there's no way to increase priority of tasks. That's definitely a problem.

The other thing is that even on the 'fastest' setting, the game gets boring waiting for your dwarves to complete their tasks (even if they immediately jump on them), especially early on when you only have 1-2 dwarves and basic equipment. I know it's kind of supposed to feel like that early on, but this is too much. I'm just staring at the screen waiting far too often.

Also, there is a time box constantly counting down. Every 30 or so minutes (15 I think on the fastest setting), a large group of mobs attack your people. They aren't generally too difficult to defeat, but it does absolutely require your attention. I like the feature, but not ALL the time. This is a crafting game, primarily, and the demographic that likes crafting and building usually doesn't like constant distractions. We want to build our giant god damn usless-but-purty constructions and landscapes.

Lastly, the non-sandbox modes are brutal. Even if you have the materials to craft something, you can't craft it until you reach enough experience in the prerequisit tech tree research. I find myself crafting 14 'dyes' or 8 diving helmets or whatnot just to get enough experience in that tech to be able to craft further. It's infuriating at times. The crafting isn't all that streamlined either. Everytime you craft something new you must drag each ingredient from your inventory to its proper place. That would be forgivable IF you weren't required to craft nearly 100% of what's possible to craft to get to the end of the tech tree. One or the other. Absolutely not both.

Like I said, this game has so much potential, and as it is, it was still fairly fun for me for at least the first time through. However, now when I play I just end up frustrated every time. It's like the designers are too concerned with 'what makes sense?' and not enough with 'what is fun?'. Streamline menus, find a new crafting/tech system, speed the game up, realtime 'increase priority of task', and don't have the mob attack timer on constantly. Maybe a mob attacks only when you steal a rune or something underground so you can choose the time.

It's mostly a solid game, and I'm sure some people will get a lot of enjoyment out of it. Make note of the date of this writing - perhaps they will update it and fix some issues. I want so badly to like it but sadly it isn't there yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Are you a fan of Dwarf Fortress? Is that why you are here?  Then turn around and head back the way you came.  I have never before missed DF's ability to streamline jobs like I do now.

Do you feel like screwing around in a world where you cannot possibly lose or die? (if your Dwarves die they just respawn in a few minutes).  Would you like to be forced into crafting Wooden Bookshelves and Cabinets with Glass in order to unlock your next tier armor (even though you can tech straight to helmets)?

Are you more interested in creating a beautiful mansion than the slaughter of your enemies?

Then this game is for you!

reviewText:
TL;DR: though this game has promise, and a few nice things about it, because of clunky tech trees, no military conrols, an uncompelling storyline, and no challenge to speak of, I'm recommending playing Terraria and Dwarf Fortress over Craft the World.

I've logged 44 hours into this game so far, and am about midway through the second world. I've been playing the campaign mode, and haven't tried the sandbox, which means the below feedback is mostly about the campaign mode. From what I've seen, sandbox mode would probably improve the mechanics.

Pros
As some of the other reviewers have pointed out, the game has some strong points. To me, these aren't so amazing that they outweigh the cons, but I'll acknowledge them:

The graphics are cute, colorful, and cartoony. Tons of fun.
The controls are pretty smooth. Keyboard controls are nice, and interacting with the world is pretty intuitive.
Music is well done, if a bit repetative.
Crafting recipes are clever - after seeing a few receipes, you start to be able to predict the next level of the tech tree. I'll get back to this in a minute.
Cons
Because it's such a mix of game genres - rogue sandbox strategy dungeon defense fortress builder - it's trying to be all things to all these genres and struggling to get close to any.

The rogue element would be more interesting if it were easier to fail - one of the reasons Dwarf Fortress is so amazingly fun is that once you learn the horrible UI, you can and will lose the game. The question is: HOW will you lose. Maybe a dwarf will be having a terrible, horrible, no-good, very bad day, and then his kitten will fall off a cliff and die, and suddenly his Bad Day will turn into a Tantrum Spiral and the next thing you know you have a single completely insane 3-year-old dwarf sitting on the floor of the Great Hall amidst the rotting corpses of her family, and the goblins are coming. Craft the World doesn't have any feeling that you're living on the edge, or that you should care about your dwarves' welfare or wants. A dwarf died? So what!? Another one will appear in 4 minutes. Outfit that one with some gear, he's just about as good.

Exploring felt too easy - what's the point of railroads that use all my iron and (buggy) elevators to speed transportation when I can just open a portal to where ever I want to go, and I can light the way with light spells that essentially let me explore the entire world without any help from dwarves at all?

The sandbox element would be more fun if it felt easier to access - particularly in the first world where the small map means that resources are scarce, I completely strip-mined my entire world of iron and barely had enough to scrape together the resources to finish the tech tree and get those last few portal peices. I had to spend it on 'fancy chandeliers' to level up my tech tree skills. This (admittedly) would work better if I were playing in sandbox mode.

Crafting & Tech Tree

The crafting window is frustrating. The UI is clunky - recipes require arranging ingredients in a specific pattern in the grid - and no easy way of doing that except with the mouse, drag and drop, drag and drop the next thing. I desperately want there to be an 'auto-fill' button, especially after you've made a recipe once - no need to drag and drop ingredients every time.

The tech tree itself is frustrating - even if you know or can guess the recipe for a 'later' element in the tech tree, you MUST complete the levels below to have access to the upper-tier recipes. There's no strategy to 'leveling up' the tech tree and you can't choose what you're interested in building towards. As you get higher and higher in the tree, the relationships between the teirs makes less and less sense. For example, you have to complete the 'luxury decorating' level in order to have access to the 'master armor' level.

Personally, I'm more interested in the strategy aspect of games, and having to build 15 'decorative mirrors' in order to get the best armor makes zero sense to me. The Tech Tree should have 'tracks' - related things that build up - and cross-track requirements (like creating steel from the resources track is required to make steel armor, but not required to see the steel armor recipe).

Also, beer is one of the mid/late-game craftable items. Dwarves without beer for most of the game? That is no fun at all.

(No) Military

Nothing pains me more than watching my expert cook throw himself at a Beholder and die a horrible death.

There's no clear way to control some Dwarves over others or assign specific dwarves to a military squad. There are essentially 3 settings for fighting:

fight a chicken or sheep: a dwarf may eventually attack it, but the chicken/sheep is too fast and the dwarf gets tired of running after it and gives up
fight a boar: attract one or two dwarves to the battle and can be somewhat successful
fight a skeleton, zombie, beholder, or some other hostile creature: ALL your dwarves come running at top speed just for the chance at a stab at it
There are no controls in the game to tell a specific group of dwarves to attack while another group stays home, or for one group to attack one creature while another group attack a different creature. You just have to give the order to attack and hope that at least a few dwarves show up.

There could be more of an element of tower defense, except your defenses are going to be attacked and maybe destroyed with every enemy wave. There's very little in the way of maze-building, mostly you're just building traps and spikes to slow down attackers - hopefully you have enough guns built up out of reach that they can fend off a wave. Keeping defenses strong for the next wave means conserving resources that you would otherwise spend on leveling up the tech tree.

I'd say that this could be a fun element of gameplay - balancing resources so that you can fend off the waves while still progressing in the game - except it's yet another gameplay element that feels extremely arbitrary. If I build bear traps, why do they disappear rather than needing to be reset? Why do cages trap zombies and not skeletons?

Game speed

You can either pause the game, or play the game, and you can't interact with dwarves when the game is paused. There is no 'slow' or 'fast' game speed to help in crisis moments or speed up boring things.

Bugs

When I started this game (about a week and a half ago), it was technically still in 'alpha', so I'll grant that there will probably be some bugs. I found a few of them.

There's an annoying bug where dwarves with nothing to do will stand around underground next to a portal instead of returning to the house, which means they can get stranded in enclosed caves if you're not careful.

My dwarves kept on falling down the elevator shaft.

Ironically, the 'send feedback' button on the main screen of the game would open one of the game folders in Windows Explorer.

Story" and Bosses

There's no storyline to speak of
recommended: there isn't really a reason to fight them except to get to the next level (and once you do that
hoursPlayed: you have to start over with the tech tree
voteText: a single dwarf
helpfulPercent:
and no fortress). The bosses are all the same (beholders and "scroll keepers") and there's no strategy to beating them besides equipping all your dwarves as best you can and then crossing your fingers.

Conclusion
If you want more interesting game progression
votesTotal: or sandbox elements
votesFunny: play Terraria. If you like micromanaging a rogue dungeon

reviewText:
I dont really know what to say about this game, but here's a delicious chocolate cake recipe.


:INGREDIENTS FOR CAKE:

2 cups white sugar

1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour

3/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder

1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda

1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder

1 teaspoon salt

2 eggs

1 cup milk

1/2 cup vegetable oil



:INGREDIENTS FOR FROSTING:

2 teaspoons vanilla extract

1 cup boiling water

3/4 cup butter

1 1/2 cups unsweetened cocoa powder

5 1/3 cups confectioners' sugar

2/3 cup milk

1 teaspoon vanilla extract


:INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour two 9 inch cake pans.

2. Use the first set of ingredients to make the cake. In a medium bowl, stir together the sugar, flour, cocoa, baking soda, baking powder and salt. Add the eggs, milk, oil and vanilla, mix for 3 minutes with an electric mixer. Stir in the boiling water by hand. Pour evenly into the two prepared pans.

3. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes in the preheated oven, until a toothpick inserted comes out clean. Cool for 10 minutes before removing from pans to cool completely.

4.To make the frosting, use the second set of ingredients. Cream butter until light and fluffy. Stir in the cocoa and confectioners' sugar alternately with the milk and vanilla. Beat to a spreading consistency.

5. Split the layers of cooled cake horizontally, cover the top of each layer with frosting, then stack them onto a serving plate. Frost the outside of the cake.

reviewText:
While the concept of this game is cool, the execution is terrible.  For a fortress management game, Craft the World is severely lacking in tools that enable the player to manage their little dwarf colony.

Basically the way dwarves are managed is that you assign tasks by clicking on objects/tiles to harvest or creatures to kill, assigning things to be crafted, and for objects to be placed.  Along with these tasks, there is also the generic task of picking up objects that are dropped when resources are harvested.  The dwarves themselves decided which of the above tasks they will do, and in what order.  From what I've seen, unless one of their skills correlates to one of the jobs (more on that later), they will simply do whatever task is quickest to complete.  The only exception to this is when selecting an enemy to attack.  In this pretty much all dwarves will drop what they are doing to attack the enemy.

There is no way for the player to prioritize tasks or to restrict dwarves to only do certain tasks.  This means that trying to multitask is pretty much impossible as dwarves focus on tasks closest to the stockpile because they are the quickest to complete, ignoring tasks further away even if the further ones are more important.  As a result things take forever to complete.  This is made even worse when you take the pathfinding into account, expecially when it comes to gathering resources.  When a dwarf is gathering resources it tries to fill its inventory before dropping things off at the stockpile.  This means that if its inventory space is 3, and it is holding 2 objects while next to the stockpile and there is group resource across the map, the dwarf will walk all the way over to the distant pile, pick up one object, then walk all the way back to the stockpile to drop the objects off when clearly it'd be more efficient to drop off what it has, then go pickup 3 objects from the distant pile.

The only real management tools the player has is a portal and the mostly worthless skills mechanic.  The portal spell opens a temporary shortcut between a tile on the map and a the stockpile.  These portals are taken into account when calculating the speed at which a task can be completed, artficially giving distant tasks a higher 'priority' in the dwarves todo list.  However, in order to keep the piority of distant tasks high the player must constantly open up new portals near distant tasks as the tasks closest to the old portal gets completed, as the further a task is from a portal, the lower its priority is.

Along with the portals, each can also have up to 3 skills that can influence which types of jobs it takes.  For example, a dwarf with the mining skill will try to mine blocks before it tries to cut down trees, even if the trees are a quicker task to complete.  Unfortunately this mechanic is almost completely worthless as each dwarf only starts with one skill, and what that skill they start with is competely worthless.  This means that you'll most likely start with a bunch of dwarves that are skilled in worthless stuff like swimming and milling, when you really need things like mining, logging, carpentry and smithing at the start of the game.  Furthermore, the only way to get new skills for a dwarf is by applying skill books to a dwarf.  These books are rare drops that you get sometimes after harvesting a resource.  Unfortunately what skills these books teach are also completely random, meaning that you might go an hour before a book drops with a skill that you need.

Overall the gameplay is excrutatingly slow and tedious.  As far as I can tell the Campaign" of the game is just a sequence of randomly generating maps where in each one you have to build a portal in order to reach the next map.  The portal pieces are hidden in secret rooms underground that you have to find.  As levels progress the maps slowly get bigger and the difficulty gets higher.  There are no special scenarios or win conditions for any of the maps as far as I can tell
date: making the Campaign feel extremely boring and repetitive after the first level.\n\nIn short

reviewText:
This game brings together the best parts of Diggles, Dungeon Keeper and Minecraft. There are a lot of items available to craft and different types of materials that can be used to build shelter. You can build traps and automated turrets, equip your dwarves with different weapons and teach them different skills using books. The goal of the game is to kill 5 guardians and rebuild the portal to the next world. There are 3 different worlds available (normal, ice, desert) with different creatures, weathers, resources and a few specific items available only in this world.

After 30 hours of gameplay on a larger size map the game becomes a bit boring. Dwarves move slowly, mana regenerates slowly (so you cannot be using portal spell too often), maximum speed of the game is x2 (I play on max speed 95% of time). There are a few minor bugs, but they don't prevent from enjoying the game - sometimes item cannot be removed from a quick access bar or dwarves behave as if their IQ dropped to one digit number. Quick access bar at the beginning seems quite small but you get used to it (and there is another one available by pressing ctrl). There is no loading a save game - game autosaves, so when you exit you come back to what you built, hence it is not possible to undo mistakes (other than to copy save files to another directory and then bring them back).

I don't remember a game released in the past few years which would be so cheap and which I would play so long - this game is definitely worth this £14.00.

I am looking forward to see some other means of transport like horses, increased maximum game speed to x5 or x10 and normal game save/load system.

reviewText:
I really like strategy games and exploration games. This new sub-genre is interesting, but overall they make poor games. This is probably the best in the sub-genre, but I wish there were more customization. The tech-tree is linear and often just makes you do things that you normally wouldn't want to do.

If you perfer 2D exploration games, there are a lot better out there.
If you perfer strategy fortress building, there are better out there.
The combination just doesn't work because there is not enough to explore and there is not enough customization in defense or building a home.

reviewText:
I don't know who the f**k figured out the shelter system but it's damn ridicilious. Once I figured out how to build up a shelter for the dwarves, it got to a point where I couldn't get my dwarves in since dwarves can't get through doors but the shelter comes incomplete once I open the hatch. So now I have a shelter which I can't use.

Also the ♥♥♥♥ing AI is horrible. 50% of the time your dwarves just stand around finding a path which haven't changed. Once you order them to attack the skellies, 1 or 2 might act and the rest just keeps gazing the scenery while their friends get slaughtered.

And the game looks ♥♥♥♥♥. So does dwarf fortress but atleast it has a solid gameplay. Uninstall this and I hope there would be a way to get my money back. This game isn't worth a penny.

reviewText:
After about 40 hours on record all completed within 2 weeks I have to say that this game is an unfinished shell that seems fun at the start and completely pointless at the end .    Dont buy this game . Its  a huge rip off of other sandbox games and its the worst one.   I bought terraria shortly after and its  1/4 the price 100x better and has a ton of replay value.

You dont control any of your dwarves in combat . you only tell them generaly what to do and where to work . its very frustrating and your minor progression is completly unsatisfying.  they added portals to make travel easier but they really just ruin the whole concept.  After beating the first world i completely lost interest.  Actually i lost interest before i beat the world . i just wanted to get it over with.

whats the point of an exploration game that lets you stay inside 100% of the time and just portal to where ever you want on the map without having to explore there to get there.......

This is a concept that is being sold as a completed game .  Dont spend 20$ on this incomplete alpha of a game .

once youve put about 20 hours into your first save file, do everything there is to do .  you will never play this game again and you will regret what you spent on it.  Dont be fooled by the bubbly animation and pictures on steam .

this game should be $2.00.

GG Portal opening simulator.

reviewText:
i've played quite a few hours of this game while in early access and as such, it is good. but i honestly thought it was still in early, as the interface is still clunky and the AI is buggy. sometimes the dwarfs just stop and tries to figure out what to do next. even if there are plenty of unfinished task close by.

the tech tree seems off, with decorative stuff being mandatory to get usefull things. you will end up with enough decorative items to get 100% on several housings before getting to the end of the tech tree.

the graphics are nice and the audio compliments the speed of the game. it is a slow pace most of the time, you just mark out what to mine/build/attack and it will be done.

as the game is now, i would not recommend it, it needs to be polished more, but if it gets the crafting UI sorted, the tech tree re-designed and the AI improved, this is one of those games where you just relax after a frustrating day, looking at your minions do your bidding.

reviewText:
Not a fan. The game does not live up to the awesome artwork.

Pros
++ The graphics are nice and polished
+ Magic system is pretty neat, but only really exists to help you bypass some of the normal cumbersome slow gameplay.

Cons
-- All game progression is slow, slow, slow.
-- My biggest issue with this game is the tech tree. Crafting progression is incredibly slow (9 hours in and I haven't even completed the first level), and the craft tree itself is illogical and obnoxious.
-- Monster/Dwarf AI and no way to prioritize tasks.
- Predictable monster waves.
- Minecraft-esque drag-and-drop crafting system is just cumbersome.
- No real campaign mode.
- Small worlds.

Check out Gnomoria or Terraria instead.
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
At this time, the polished artwork temporarily hides the flaws of this game. While not game-breaking, the flaws make you realize you are playing an unfinished shell of a game that is simply wasting your time attempting to compensate for those flaws.

Pros
++ Polished Artwork and original style
+ Little to no bugs or game-breaking errors

Cons
-- Bad AI for Dwarves and Monsters
-- Very Small Worlds
-- No Campaign or Plot
- Very limited bestiary
- Constant and predictable monster waves
- Boring/slow crafting system
- No autofill for recipes - Lots of pointless click and drag
- Limited in-game resources prohibit creativity

Ex. The player controlled spells like the Portal Spell are merely tricks that lets you bypass the slow gameplay and clunky AI of your minions.

reviewText:
Summary: Recommended, but with a BIG caveat

I love the game, and won't bother extolling its virtues since they are described so thoroughly in many other reviews -- but beware of crashes!  I reached a point in one level where the game inevitably crashes, and there is absolutely nothing I can do to remedy it.  Every time I restart the game, it automatically reloads its auto-save (which it seems to create every 15 seconds or so), so it's always seconds away from blowing up again.  There's no way to go back to an earlier save point because there aren't any -- you can't manually save the game.  My only option is to restart the whole level, which means abandoning about 14 hours of gameplay.  I'm NOT replaying 14 hours of this or any game, so as much as I like it, this game is now effectively dead to me.

The point being, unless the game NEVER crashes, you're going to find yourself in this same boat eventually.  If you can stomach that possibility, go ahead and buy this game, it's definitely a lot of fun.

reviewText:
I am quite motivated in giving this game a bad review.
I hope i can help other people to be mislead like i was by the 90 % positive reviews.

This game is boring and clunky.

I think this kind of casual game could be nice to play : no pressure, just a pleasant relaxing game.
But this one fails at this because the gameplay is not pleasant enough. you need to be crafting stuff all the time to advance and you can't take time to watch your dwarves and remain efficient at the same time.

I don't think i'll open the game again. Even at low price, it is not worth my time/

reviewText:
I am a fan of succinct and to the point reviews. I will do my best to adhere to my own rules with this review.

Pros:
- Technology tree is awesome
- Graphics are extremely well done (specifically the environment/textures/objects). Though I found the character sprites a bit on the cartoonish side (including the enemies - just a minor personal gripe).
- Enough going on to keep you busy for several hours.
- I loved the idea of an Altar/Shrine!

Cons:
- Crafting interface is unforgivable. You must drag and drop each instance of the resource required. WHAT? Whose idea was that?
- Not enough to work towards (while my own time with this game was brief - I was able to get a good sense of this aspect by watching several in-depth YouTube reviews)
- No risk/reward mechanism. You won't really die if a ginormous Zombie smacks you around and falls on you! I prefer challenge and some sense of realism!
- The world needs to be much much bigger. Think Terraria sized worlds.
- You can't truly take control over the characters. Sorry, I like full control Yes, I am a control freak when it comes to these kind of games.

Overall I feel this game needs a lot of improvement to get it to where it needs to be.
In the meantime I will get my fix by playing Terraria!

reviewText:
I'd like to recommend this game but the AI is truly broken.  The dwaves will run around in a panic and not rest or eat.  They run into monsters and do nothing.  They stand around doing nothing when there is all kinds of goods to pick up.   Dwarves will walk into enemy camps and do nothing while the enemy beats the stuffing out of them.  I'll open a portal for them to get to safety and they just stand there instead of using the portal and going to safety.  Dwarves will seal themselves into a chamber without figuring the right order to put the blocks down to ensure they can get out.  Dwarves will fall into water and drown unless you can take manual control and get them out.    Loot will just inexplicably disappear from the map.
CRTL R - Supposed to make all dwarves rest that are under 70% health.  They are at their beds standing next to it and momentarily make a snoring sound.  But they are tired and won't lie down.  Same problem if you slect them individually and tell them to go rest so they can heal.  They'll just stand there.
CRTL E - all hungry dwarves are supposed to eat.  They don't
You can select them individually and try and get them to do one of those things when they are getting the crap kicked out of them, or if they are standing around doing nothing.  Not going to work though.

Other problems not bugs but just present game features -

If you click on attack every dwarf no matter where they are will ALL run to the one enemy.
There's really no way to assign individual dwarves to tasks.  They just do them based on what the AI decides.
There's no way to sell or stuff you mine to the merchant for goods, except for gold coins that you randomly find.
You'll find yourself constantly running out of resources, so a trade system (even an unbalanced one) would be helpful
Keyboard interaction is limited.  You will find yourself clicking, and double clicking to select a resources.
You want to select a certain dwarf - you must click on the dwarf.

On a postive note:
Pretty graphics.
Developer seems like a nice guy.  He notes the bugs I report but no response on an update or a known issue.

So, the game is pretty much unplayable in it's present state unless you just want to manually control each dwarf that has become unresponsive and walk them into a monster and let them die.  Then you'll get another one after a while.  But you will start from scratch and lose the skills the dwarf has aquired.  If you don't do thist, your unresponsive dwarf will either run around amlessly until is gets killed and you will lose the equipment you made for it (about 80% change of that), or it will just stand there and do absolutely nothing (which costs you one dwarf slot).

Hopefully the developer will fix these problems and get the game where it needs to be AI wise.

reviewText: For the last 3 days iv been playing this game since I started iv restarted the game over 20 times due to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ spawns and just getting killed over and over again other than the cluster ♥♥♥♥ of a tech tree making you make a bunch of unnecessary crap that you spent so hard trying to get resources if there is anything I would fix about this game it would be the Tech Tree being able to build a house before the first wave is like a race to the restarting the game witch makes the game a little stressful to play until you get your shelter fully complete other than that the game is great super addicting since iv been playing iv gotten 3 of my friends to buy it over all 8/10 just fix that tech tree and we got a solid 10/10 great job on the game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is actually pretty good but it is shamed by its clunky interface. You have to single drag every ingridient into the crafting system, every time. Its such a paint in the ♥♥♥. Also to place items you need to drag and drop to your small hotbar.
This game have UI designed for a smartphone or tablet. Drag drop crafting very very quickly loose its novelty, and after that its just a chore.
